content: I'm conflicted about puzzles that can be solved with a built-in library function. It might be overkill, but considering each cell you have a system of linear equations that can be solved with numpy.linalg.solve(). Maybe if the test cases were bigger that wouldn't be a feasible solution?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: If the comments are anything to go by, it looks like there are several ways to solve this. Pretty cool!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle. Items like this are great for measuring IQ.  Very low dependence on knowledge and highly g-loaded.
the test and validator for the 11x11 case are the same. must be a copy/paste error ^^

Hey pardouin,

There was a movie with that title :)
Where did you get this griddler?

'For each cell of the grid, you're given the number or fortresses that share the same row and/or the same column.'

I think this needs to be rephrased. At first test 
212   O..
322   O.O
201   ...

The cell with three. None of row and column has three fortresses. It's not sum either, 2+2 = 4
An example how to read the grid would be handy.

Note: I'm aware that once you find the solution, there's not much to do, but I still rated it hard because the solution is not obvious. I can easily imagine people struggling a bit with it and trying overcomplicated solutions (that would probably fail due to big numbers in the constraints).

There are three fortresses that share the same row and/or column: (0, 0), (1, 0) and (1, 2).
I'll try to rephrase that or provide a detailed example in the statement.

Backstory: few years ago, I was recreating logic games like minesweeper, sudoku, etc, for educationnal purpose, but it was a bit frustrating to recreate already existing games so I tried to come up with a game of my own. I ended up with this fortress game, named indeed after Akira Kurosawa's movie.
(Note that the rules are pretty simple and natural so it's very likely that this puzzle has already been adressed by someone else.)
So I created a playable version of it that keeps track of your best time for a given size, and it was surprisingly fun to play, at some point you must develop new techniques to save time :-)

More seriously :

My solution is little different of yours, I only use lines, and if unknown cells exists, I do a pass and can conclude with a simple counting on unknown cell.
(in fact this is only needed for the test/validator of the first 3x3 and the validator of 5x5 due to the empty column)

The puzze is interesting.

My goal was to have test cases as big as possible because in theory even with n = 5000 you could still solve it - the fast solution is only O(n^2) - but unfortunately the I/O format doesn't allow more than ~1000 chars in total for the input so a 5000 x 5000 grid is out of question.

At least n = 31 prevents from using the usual techniques that are used for griddlers (often based on a mix of elimination and backtracking), so it's not that bad.

It indeed allows for O(n^3) solutions, like those based on linear algebra, but well, why not. It's still an interesting way to solve the problem. And maybe if a user solves it with numpy, then takes a look at other solutions and sees that there are short solutions without numpy, it will motivate him to give it another try without numpy ?
